feed.title: All blog posts featured by QuantStack team
feed.subtitle: Atom feed for QuantStack website blog page

entry.title: Create your own layers in JupyterGIS
entry.content: JupyterGIS-tiler is a JupyterGIS extension that lets you use a notebook to process your (Xarray) data and make it available as raster tiles, so that it can be visualized in JupyterGIS.

entry.title: C++ in Jupyter — Interpreting C++ in the Web
entry.content: Scientists and engineers utilize programming languages not only to build software systems but also to drive interactive exploratory workflows. They leverage developer tools to explore and reason through problems effectively.

entry.title: JupyterLite 0.6.0 is released! 🎉
entry.content: The new 0.6.0 release includes a number of new features, bug fixes, and enhancements. This release also brings significant improvements to the user experience and new customization options for JupyterLite deployments.

entry.title: JupyterLab 4.4 and Notebook 7.4 are available!
entry.content: JupyterLab 4.4 has been released! This new minor release of JupyterLab includes 28 new features and enhancements, 76 bug fixes, 63 maintenance tasks and 34 documentation improvements.

entry.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
entry.content: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2024 cohort of contributors.

entry.title: Making Qt collaborative using CRDTs
entry.content: A journal on creating a collaborative application with Qt

entry.title: R in the Browser: Announcing Our WebAssembly Distribution
entry.content: R is now available in emscripten-forge, enabling the Xeus-R kernel in JupyterLite.

entry.title: Real-time collaboration and collaborative editing for GIS workflows with Jupyter and QGIS
entry.content: We are excited to announce JupyterGIS, a web-based, collaborative, and extensible interface for GIS, leveraging the JupyterLab application framework and integrating seamlessly with the Jupyter notebook interface.

entry.title: PyData Paris 2025 Keynotes
entry.content: We are thrilled to announce the keynote speakers for the upcoming PyData Paris 2025, the leading gathering of the open-source data science and AI/ML community in France.

entry.title: Announcing JupyterCAD 3.0
entry.content: We are thrilled to introduce JupyterCAD 3.0, the newest version of the collaborative CAD modeler designed for JupyterLab.

entry.title: Sparrow
entry.content: We are thrilled to introduce Sparrow, a new library designed to simplify the integration of Apache Arrow’s columnar format into C++ applications.

entry.title: JupyterLite Terminal
entry.content: QuantStack are delighted to announce that we have been working on a new Terminal for JupyterLite.

entry.title: Automate your releases with the Jupyter Releaser 🚀
entry.content: Jupyter Releaser is an automation tool developed by the Jupyter team to streamline and standardize the release process across Jupyter projects.

entry.title: QuantStack Steps Up to Support Apache Arrow with New Dedicated Team
entry.content: We are thrilled to announce that QuantStack is starting a new team dedicated to the maintenance and development of Apache Arrow.

entry.title: Interactive Mapping with ipyopenlayers
entry.content: In this article, we present the main features of ipyopenlayers and demonstrate how this library can transform your geospatial data into dynamic, interactive visualizations.

entry.title: Announcing the 2023 cohort of Jupyter distinguished contributors
entry.content: We are delighted to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2023 cohort.

author.name: on behalf of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributors

entry.title: Ipydatagrid is now part of Project Jupyter
entry.content: Today, we are proud to announce that the ipydatagrid open source project has been incorporated into Project Jupyter as part of the Jupyter Widgets subproject.

author.name: on behalf of the Jupyter Widgets Council

entry.title: Introducing Mamba 2.0
entry.content: We are excited to present the first release candidate of Mamba 2.0, a significant upgrade to the mamba package manager. This update brings considerable enhancements for both users and developers, following an extensive year-long development effort.

entry.title: QuantStack open-source internship program
entry.content: Today, we are announcing a new internship program that aims to empower a new cohort of open-source contributors and future maintainers to make an impact within our ecosystem.

entry.title: JupyterCAD 2.0
entry.content: We are thrilled to introduce JupyterCAD 2.0, the newest version of the JupyterLab-based CAD modeler.

entry.title: JupyterGIS
entry.content: We are thrilled to announce that the European Space Agency (ESA) is funding our proposal “Real-time collaboration and collaborative editing for GIS workflows with Jupyter and QGIS.”

entry.title: Commit!
entry.content: Open-source projects are not just about the latest exciting updates and features, but also the principles and people that drive these projects to success. In this blog post, I reflect on the dynamics…

entry.title: In memoriam: Fanny Loustau Chartez
entry.content: It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our colleague and friend, Fanny Loustau Chartez, who served as the Chief Financial Officer of QuantStack since 2021.

entry.title: Announcing PyData Paris 2024
entry.content: We are thrilled to announce the upcoming PyData Paris 2024, the gathering of the open-source data science and AI/ML community in France. PyData Paris will take place at the Cité des Sciences from September 25 to September 26, 2024.

entry.title: Meet Xeus-R: a future-proof Jupyter kernel for R
entry.content: Today, we, a collaborative team led by Romain François and supported by QuantStack, are thrilled to announce the initial release of Xeus-R, a future-proof Jupyter kernel for R.

entry.title: QuantStack: 2023 in review
entry.content: Since QuantStack was founded in 2016, we have remained committed to releasing our work under permissive open-source licenses. Here are some highlights of the 2023 achievements. Buckle up!

entry.title: Recent keyboard navigation improvements in Jupyter
entry.content: Upcoming versions of JupyterLab (4.1.0) and Notebook (7.1.0) will include major keyboard accessibility fixes.

entry.title: And Voici!
entry.content: Voici (meaning “here is” in French) is a novel project reshaping Jupyter-based interactive dashboards by combining Voilà and JupyterLite features. It facilitates the creation of dynamic, in-browser environments for data visualization and exploration.

entry.title: Plug your application into the Jupyter world
entry.content: Kernels are a simple but powerful abstraction in the Jupyter architecture. They encapsulate language interpreters and make them accessible through a standardized interface. This is the key to…

entry.title: Voilà 0.5 - Homecoming
entry.content: Following the launch of Jupyter Notebook 7, it is now Voilà’s turn to join the JupyterLab family. In Version 0.5.0, the front-end of Voilà has been rebuilt from scratch using JupyterLab 4.0 components, just like in the case of Notebook 7.

entry.title: Announcing Jupyter Notebook 7
entry.content: Jupyter Notebook 7 is the most significant release of the Jupyter Notebook in years. Some highlights of this release include real-time collaboration, interactive debugging, table of contents, theming and dark mode, internationalization, improved accessibility, compact view on mobile devices.

entry.title: 🎉 JupyterCon 2023 recordings now live on YouTube! 🎉
entry.content: Get ready to relive the magic of JupyterCon 2023, because the long-awaited moment is finally here! The JupyterCon YouTube channel has just dropped a treasure trove of content — all the talk and keynote recordings from the most epic conference of the year.

entry.title: A theme editor for JupyterLab
entry.content: To lower the bar for customizing JupyterLab we created a new tool providing a simple interface for tuning the JupyterLab appearance interactively.

entry.title: Collaborative CAD in JupyterLab
entry.content: Introducing JupyterCAD, a tool that integrates Computer-Aided Design (CAD) capabilities into JupyterLab.

entry.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
entry.content: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2022 cohort of contributors.

entry.title: Embed interactive itkwidgets 3D renderings into JupyterLite deployments
entry.content: A tutorial that demonstrates a zero-server, interactive 3D rendering notebook and walks through the quick and easy configuration that can be customized to your needs.

entry.title: Improving the accessibility of Jupyter
entry.content: This article presents some of the recent accessibility improvements in the Jupyter Notebook codebase.

entry.title: A Jupyter kernel for GNU Octave
entry.content: We are happy to announce the xeus-octave project, a Jupyter kernel for GNU Octave. Xeus-octave was created by Giulio Girardi, recently joined by Antoine Prouvost - and has been incorporated into the Project Jupyter governance.

entry.title: QuantStack: 2022 in review
entry.content: 2022 was an amazing year of innovation for the open-source developers at QuantStack. Developments range from major improvements to the Jupyter project to the packaging ecosystem and high-performance computing.

entry.title: Managing conflicts with Mamba
entry.content: A key aspect of package management is finding a set of compatible versions of the required packages. Indeed, even in the case when few packages are explicitly required, second-order dependencies may…

entry.title: JupyterCon is back in 2023
entry.content: JupyterCon 2023 will be held May 10–12 (Thursday to Friday) in the city of light, Paris, France at the largest science museum in Europe, the Cité des Sciences et de l’Industrie.

entry.title: Accelerating JupyterLab
entry.content: The next major release of JupyterLab will be significantly faster than previous versions. This was achieved both through systematic tracking of performance bugs and through significant upgrades to the Jupyter communication protocol and rendering mechanism for documents.

entry.title: Upgrading nbgrader
entry.content: Project Jupyter provides a broad collection of open-source tools for interactive computing that has become ubiquitous in data science and scientific computing, and is very popular in educational…

entry.title: Visual programming in JupyterLab with Blockly
entry.content: When moving from block-based programming to a more classical language like Python, students often have to switch to a completely new environment. In order to provide a smooth ramp of complexity for learners, we designed a JupyterLab extension for Blockly so that Jupyter can be used from the very first steps of their learning journey.

entry.title: Mamba meets JupyterLite
entry.content: JupyterLite is a Jupyter distribution that runs entirely in the web browser without any server components. To achieve this, all language kernels must also run in the browser. A significant benefit of…

entry.title: Inspector JupyterLab
entry.content: JupyterLab provides multiple ways to improve your coding workflow: code highlighting, code completion, theming, debugger with rich variable rendering and more.

entry.title: HTML5 <canvas> based renderer for Matplotlib in Pyodide
entry.content: In this post, we present a new backend for Matplotlib enabling the rendering of figures in the browser by leveraging the <canvas> element. This showcases how JavaScript and Python can interact with each other, thanks to Pyodide.

entry.title: The future of mamba
entry.content: The recent adoption of libmamba by the conda project was a great validation of our work. Several other game-changing innovations are in the works by the mamba team. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Congratulations, Distinguished Contributors!
entry.content: We are proud to announce the recipients of the Jupyter Distinguished Contributor (JDC) award for the 2021 cohort of contributors.

entry.title: Jupyter Everywhere
entry.content: Easily embed a console, a notebook, or a fully-fledged IDE on any web page.

entry.title: ROS2 support for Zethus
entry.content: Zethus is an Open Source library for Robot visualization in the browser. Initially developed by Rapyuta Robotics, it provides a web-based…

entry.title: QuantStack: 2021 in review
entry.content: This was a crazy year of innovation for the open-source team at QuantStack. From JupyterLab to the packaging ecosystem and high-performance computing, we made some major strides in all areas, while almost doubling the size of the team.

entry.content: Voilà turns Jupyter notebooks into standalone applications without requiring any modification to the content. You want to share your content with non-technical readers? Just call Voilà with the…

entry.content: We have just released Xeus 2.0. This is a major release of the library. While it includes backward-incompatible changes, they are very limited and upgrading your kernels should be relatively easy…

entry.title: Le calcul haute performance au service de l'innovation (in French)
entry.content: Led by Professor Marc Massot (Center for Applied Mathematics), the HPC@Maths initiative aims at developing a strong expertise in high-performance computing at École Polytechnique. This project is supported by the X Foundation, and by QuantStack.

entry.title: How we made Jupyter notebooks collaborative with Yjs

entry.title: RetroLab - A JupyterLab distribution with a retro look and feel
entry.content: RetroLab is an alternative JupyterLab distribution, built from the ground-up, providing a notebook interface with a retro look and feel. Currently at version 3.0, JupyterLab provides an advanced…

entry.title: Rhumba, the fast R distribution is available on Windows

entry.title: JupyterLab 3.0 is Released!
entry.content: The 3.0 release of JupyterLab brings many new features to users and substantial improvements to the extension distribution system.

entry.title: Interactive C++ for Data Science
entry.content: This post will discuss some applications of Cling developed to support data science researchers. In particular, interactively probing data and interfaces makes complex libraries and complex data more accessible users.

entry.title: Bye bye Boost.SIMD, Welcome XSimd
entry.content: Boost.simd provides a C++ abstraction of vector type, allowing for efficient vectorization of array computations. It has been (optionally) used as part of the expression template engine of Pythran for a long time, a great collaboration that led to several patches in boost.simd, and great performance for Pythran.

entry.title: A Diagram Editor for JupyterLab

entry.title: Fast Reductions in Xtensor with Xsimd

entry.title: Scientific Computing in a Polyglot World with Xtensor
